Award.AwardTitle: RAPID Collaborative Research: Resilient and resistant urban forests: the role of landscape configuration and socioeconomic legacy in understanding tree response to hurricane
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hurricane Irma caused severe wind and water damage across Florida. Damage to urban forests was widespread. Many trees were uprooted or lost leaves and limbs. As in previous storms, tree damage from Irma is unlikely to be felt equally across communities. Since urban forests provide many important services, understanding what causes differences in impacts between communities is critical to recovery. Patterns of damage may depend on proximity to buildings and which species were present. Management practices, as well as average household income and age of housing, are also likely to be important. Therefore, the goal of this project is to understand how local ecological, social and economic conditions relate to the severity of damage to urban forests from Hurricane Irma. Irma provides a unique and urgent opportunity to learn how urban forests are affected by hurricanes, allowing communities to better predict where tree loss may be high. This will lead to better preparation and effective recovery plans for future storm events. Presentations and workshops will provide information to urban planners and tree care professionals, helping improve urban forest design, tree risk assessment and storm management efforts.

This project will provide an opportunity to directly evaluate urban tree canopy responses to hurricanes, and differences in tree damage related to biophysical and social characteristics. This project will build on existing measurements, utilizing field inventory data obtained in the months prior to the storm in Tampa, Gainesville, and Orange County, Florida. Field plots will be re-visited to obtain post-storm data assessing tree failure. These data will be used in conjunction with remotely sensed data obtained before and after the storm, as well as census data to establish socioeconomic context. This combination of field measurements, census data, and remotely sensed data products will allow inference about relationships between socioeconomic and forest structural factors and tree failure. The findings and predictions will directly address larger-scale questions about how urban forest ecosystems are altered in the face of future disturbance scenarios. This project will also improve estimates of the overall consequences of hurricanes to urban forests, allowing policy makers to make better decisions to manage the ecosystem services of this important resource.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hurricanes represent one of the most significant disturbances regularly experienced by United States residents living along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts and throughout the Caribbean. For this region’s many urban inhabitants, the combined effects of storm surge, extreme wind, and saturated soils associated with tropical cyclones can wreak havoc on the trees and vegetation that are critically important for making cities more livable. Professionals who manage urban trees in hurricane-prone regions have limited data to draw on when making decisions regarding the relative safety of trees - information which is needed to prevent ill-advised tree removal or retention. While some aspects of tree resiliency to hurricanes have been relatively well studied (i.e., the impact of species and certain tree wood defects), industry professionals have begun to acknowledge the potential importance of external protective factors in determining which trees will likely weather the next tropical storm they face. 

In this NSF-funded research, we investigated the impact of a tree’s surroundings on the likelihood that it would break apart or tip over during a hurricane. Specifically, we used data collected in three Florida sites (Tampa, Gainesville, and unincorporated Orange County) just prior to Hurricane Irma to assess how proximity to neighboring trees and other above-ground structures affected damage to trees of different ages/size, species, and condition. Additionally, we investigated trees in a range of locales to determine if differing demographics related to the wealth, population density, age, homeownership status, and racial-makeup of a neighborhood were related to damage observed after the storm. 

Overall, the observed tree damage on our three sites was minimal and largely limited to the loss of branches less than 25 cm in size. Despite past research and anecdotal evidence suggesting that trees are more resilient when planted in groups, we did not detect any significant protective benefit from the presence of neighboring trees or buildings. Moreover, we failed to detect any relationship between the demographic factors assessed and storm-related tree damage. In contrast, we did find that tree damage was increased among larger trees and in areas that had a greater proportion of trees perceived as being intolerant to high winds. We also detected a significant increase in damage as the diversity of trees in an area increased which may be attributed to avoidance of planting more wind resistant native species, like live oak (Quercus virginiana). 

The results of this work will directly inform urban tree management efforts with regard to species selection and provide further evidence that some aspects of current tree risk assessment best practices appear to be useful predictors of tree safety in developed areas. That said, we failed to find evidence supporting consideration of surrounding wind protection factors when determining the fate of open-grown trees with questionable safety. Further study, in particular reassessment of tree failure into the future, is an area that deserves additional attention in research.
